author: gcolvin

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, I am a bigger fan of the strategy being taken this time vs previous times.  I like a human readable executable spec over a provable spec (which I think is what was tried in the past).

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: More specifically though, written in a way so as to prefer readability over utility.

author: gcolvin
content: Damn.  I'm much better at English and math.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would be fine with some other language, but the critical piece is leaving out optimizations and strongly preferring readability over performance.

author: sky.cactus
content: Most code is (and all current Ethereum clients are) written with at least some amount of preference for performance, and often with a secondary goal of maintainability, with readability coming in third.  Unfortunately, maintainability often decreases readability.  When authoring code *specifically* for readability (as a specification), sometimes the trade-offs you make in terms of maintainability are different.  This requires much more testing and test coverage to get right, and changes are harder, but it can yield great benefits when it comes to readability, especially for casual observers.

author: gcolvin
content: Sometimes the whole point of a change is performance.  Setting that aside, I know how to write technical English.  I have little skill at reading or writing Python.

author: sky.cactus
content: For most changes, I suspect the English part will still dominate.

author: sky.cactus
content: For many changes to Ethereum, the actual code change is quite small.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Sometimes the whole point of a change is performance.
For consensus changes, we can still represent the behavior change regardless of *why* the change was made.  The key is that the executable spec is written to be readable, but it still **MUST** fully represent an Ethereum client and be able to pass the full consensus test suite.

author: gcolvin
content: So my most recent EIPs are expressed mainly declaratively -- here are the rules valid code must follow.  I don't know whether Python is good for that.  Then there is an algorithm for checking the rules.  It doesn't matter what it is, just that there is one that can run in linear time.  I have it in Go now. First, because I need to test it in a real client for  correctness.  And second because I need to test it in a real client for performance.  To do that in Python I'd need to learn yet another computer language and how to work in yet another client.  And I fear any performance gains would not be apparent in such a slow language.  Pain for a demonstrable lack of gain.

author: gcolvin
content: I guess I'd pretty much want to write them the way I do now -- English plus code for whatever client I tested the code in -- and let someone else translate to Python if the devs think it is worth doing.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think that this is just a matter of finding a co-author.  I'm a big fan of collaborative EIPs and I think this could be a great opportunity for the apprenticeship program or people who are interested in contributing but aren't sure how to start.
